A brief introduction to Web Components

Basics

Struggling with complex HTML and associated styles and scripts to render custom UI controls and use them multiple times?

Need to support different javascript frameworks?

Why not just use Web Components?

Web Components are a great tool to deliver high-quality user experiences without complicated frameworks or build steps. And they donâ€™t run the risk of becoming obsolete.

What are Web Components?

Web components consist of three different technologies that are often used together:

  1. Custom Elements - Custom elements allow web developers to define new HTML tags, extend existing ones, and create reusable UI components.
  2. Shadow DOM - Shadow DOM provides a way for an element to own, render, and style a chunk of DOM that's separate from the rest of the page.
  3. HTML templates - <template> allows you to declare fragments of the DOM which are parsed, insert at page load, and can be activated later at runtime.

Custom Elements

Simple example:

                    
class ZepHeadline extends HTMLElement {
    connectedCallback() {
        this.innerHTML = `<h1>Zeppelin</h1>`;
    }
}
customElements.define('zep-headline', ZepHeadline);

See the Pen Custom Element demo by Joerg Schneider (@byjs-dev) on CodePen.
